details.title: A least-squares approach to analyzing life-stress relationship in step-stress accelerated life tests

p: Siew-Leng Teng received the M. Sc. degree (2000) in statistics and the B. Sc. [Hons.] degree (1999) in mathematics from the National University of Singapore (NUS).
Her research interests include biostatistics, accelerated life testing, and survival analysis.
Kwee-Poo Yeo received the M. Sc. and Ph.D. degrees in statistics from Cornell University, NY.

He was with the National University of Singapore. He is now with Lilly-NUS Centre for Clinical Pharmacology Pte Ltd. His research interests are in nonparametric methods, survival analysis, and biostatistics.

details.abstract: A new approach is proposed for the data analysis of failure-censored step-stress accelerated life tests with exponential failures, following an assumed log-linear life-stress relationship. This approach, transformed least squares: (1) provides closed-form parameter estimates; (2) motivates a simple statistic for life-stress relationship verification; and (3) appreciably simplifies the derivation of optimal test plans. The proposed D-statistic has good power and compares reasonably well with likelihood-ratio test statistic. Estimates are unbiased and exact for failure-step tests of any sample size. The derived optimal test plans agree with those derived using maximum likelihood estimation.

references.title: The power of approximate tests for the regression coefficients in a gamma regression model

context.text: Reference [1] verified a log-linear life-stress relationship for Gamma failures using a LR test.

links.abstract: A gamma regression model which has wide application in life-testing and analysis of point processes is considered. Approximate statistical tests for the regression coefficients based on maximum likelihood and weighted least squares fits of the model are considered. The power and significance level properties of the tests are evaluated for a model with a single regressor variate when the underlying gamma distributions have the same shape parameter. The tests give good control over the actual sign...

references.text: A. M. Al-Abood, D. H. Young, "The power of approximate tests for the regression coefficients in a gamma regression model", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. R-35, pp. 216-220, June 1986.

references.title: The power of approximate tests for the regression coefficients in a gamma regression model

context.text: A general goodness-of-fit approach for censored data is in [2].

references.text: J. R. Michael, R. William, "The power of approximate tests for the regression coefficients in a gamma regression model", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 21, pp. 435-441, Dec. 1979.

references.title: Accelerated Testing&#821Statistical Models, Test Plans and Data Analysis

context.text: References [3] and [4] suggest using LR and lack-of-fit tests for constant-stress ALT.
This transformation involves the unknown parameters \$\theta_i\$, \$\theta_{i+1}\$ [3].
The Nelson cumulative model [3] is used, and the equivalent times follow a Weibull distribution.
When \$\beta\$ is unknown, a pre-estimate of \$\beta\$ is used for the ALT analysis [3].

references.text: W. B. Nelson, Accelerated Testing&#821Statistical Models Test Plans and Data Analysis, 1990, Wiley.

references.title: Least squares estimation for the inverse power law for accelerated life tests

context.text: References [3] and [4] suggest using LR and lack-of-fit tests for constant-stress ALT.
Reference [4] discussed LS estimation for constant-stress ALT failures.
The variances of such LSE are slightly larger than their Cramer–Rao lower bounds [4].

references.text: H. D. Kahn, "Least squares estimation for the inverse power law for accelerated life tests", Applied Statistics, vol. 28, no. 1, pp. 40-46, 1979.

references.title: Optimum accelerated life tests for the Weibull and extreme-value distributions

context.text: Reference [7]obtains the MLE for a 2-parameter Weibull distribution under the Inverse Power Law.

links.abstract: This paper presents charts for optimum accelerated life-test plans for estimating a simple linear relationship between an accelerating stress and product life, which has a Weibull or smallest extreme value distribution, when the data are to be analyzed before all tests units fail. The plans show that one need not run all test units to failure and that more units ought to be tested at low test stresses than at high ones. The plans are illustrated with a voltage-accelerated life test of an electri...

references.text: W. Q. Meeker, W. B. Nelson, "Optimum accelerated life tests for the Weibull and extreme-value distributions", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. R-24, pp. 321-331, 1975.

references.title: Optimum 3-step step-stress tests

context.text: Reference [8]obtains optimal 3-step (time-step) step-stress test plans for exponential life data.
A modified 4 : 2 : 1 compromise ALT plan [8] is used.
A modified 4 : 2 : 1 compromise ALT design [8] is used for failure-step ALT simulation.
Following the 4 : 2 : 1 test plan [8], choose: \$n_1 = 29\$, \$n_2 = 14\$, \$n_3 = 7\$.

links.abstract: Optimum simple step-stress accelerated life testing plans have practical limitations. They highly depend upon the assumption of a linear relationship between stress and time-to-failure and use only two extreme stresses that can cause irrelevant failure modes. Thus, 3-step plans are preferable. In this paper, the authors derive the optimum quadratic plan and propose and evaluate a 3-step test plan, the compound linear, as an alternative to the optimum simple step-stress plan and optimum quadratic...

references.text: I. H. Khamis, J. J. Higgins, "Optimum 3-step step-stress tests", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 45, pp. 341-345, 1996.

references.title: Optimum simple step-stress accelerated life tests with censoring

context.text: Reference [9]discusses an optimal plan for a simple ALT with censoring for exponential life data with log-linear relationship.
Optimal stress-change times for a failure-step ALT and a time-step ALT are identical to those established by the conventional variance optimization via the MLE method [9], [11], [12].
This agrees with [9], as derived via MLE asymptotic variance minimization for uncensored failure-step ALT.
By optimizing the variance from (6), lemma 4 gives an optimal stress-change timeWhen there is no censoring,which agrees with [9] and [13].

links.abstract: The authors present the optimum simple time-step and failure-step stress accelerated life tests for the case where a prespecified censoring time is involved. An exponential life distribution with a mean that is a log-linear function of stress, and a cumulative exposure model are assumed. The authors obtain the optimum test plans to minimize the asymptotic variance of the maximum-likelihood estimator of the mean life at a design stress. Nomographs for the optimum time-step stress test are also gi...

references.text: D. S. Bai, M. S. Kim, S. H. Lee, "Optimum simple step-stress accelerated life tests with censoring", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 38, pp. 528-531, 1989.

references.title: Analysis of step-stress accelerated-life-test data: A new approach

context.text: Reference [10] uses ML for parameter estimation in a multi-censored ALT.

links.abstract: A linear cumulative exposure model (LCEM) is used to analyze data from a step-stress accelerated-life-test, in particular, those with failure-free life (FFL). FFL is characterized by a location parameter in the distribution. For the 2-parameter Weibull distribution, the Nelson cumulative exposure model is a special case of LCEM. Under LCEM a general expression is derived for computing the maximum likelihood estimator (MLE) of stress-dependent distribution parameters under multiple censoring. The...

references.text: L. C. Tang, Y. S. Sun, T. N. Goh, H. L. Ong, "Analysis of step-stress accelerated-life-test data: A new approach", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 45, pp. 69-74, Mar. 1996.

references.title: Accelerated life testing&#821Step-stress models and data analysis

context.text: Optimal stress-change times for a failure-step ALT and a time-step ALT are identical to those established by the conventional variance optimization via the MLE method [9], [11], [12].

links.abstract: This paper presents statistical models and methods for analyzing accelerated life-test data from step-stress tests. Maximum likelihood methods provide estimates of the parameters of such models, the life distribution under constant stress, and other information. While the methods are applied to the Weibull distribution and inverse power law, they apply to many other accelerated life test models. These methods are illustrated with step-stress data on time to breakdown of an electrical insulation.

references.text: W. B. Nelson, "Accelerated life testing̵Step-stress models and data analysis", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. R-29, pp. 103-108, 1980.

context.text: Optimal stress-change times for a failure-step ALT and a time-step ALT are identical to those established by the conventional variance optimization via the MLE method [9], [11], [12].

references.title: Optimum simple step-stress plans for accelerated life testing

context.text: By optimizing the variance from (6), lemma 4 gives an optimal stress-change timeWhen there is no censoring,which agrees with [9] and [13].

links.abstract: This paper presents optimum plans for simple (two stresses) step-stress tests where all units are run to failure. Such plans minimize the asymptotic variance of the maximum likelihood estimator (MLE) of the mean life at a design stress. The life-test model consists of: 1) an exponential life distribution with 2) a mean that is a log-linear function of stress, and 3) a cumulative exposure model for the effect of changing stress. Two types of simple step-stress tests are considered: 1) a time-step...

references.text: R. Miller, W. B. Nelson, "Optimum simple step-stress plans for accelerated life testing", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. R-32, pp. 59-65, Mar. 1983.
